Hamill was born on September 25, 1951, in Oakland, California. He began his acting career in the 1970s, appearing in small roles on television shows and films. In 1977, he landed the role of a lifetime when he was cast as Luke Skywalker in George Lucas's space epic, Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope.

Hamill's portrayal of the young Jedi Knight earned him widespread recognition and critical acclaim. He went on to reprise the role in The Empire Strikes Back (1980) and Return of the Jedi (1983), becoming synonymous with the character.

In addition to his work on Star Wars, Hamill has had a prolific career in voice acting, providing voices for animated shows such as Batman: The Animated Series, The New Batman Adventures, and Justice League Unlimited. He has also appeared in numerous live-action films and television shows, including The Flash, Knight Rider, and SpongeBob SquarePants.

Hamill has received numerous awards and nominations for his work, including multiple Annie and Daytime Emmy Awards. He has also been honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and has been inducted into the Hollywood Museum's Walk of Fame.

In recent years, Hamill has become a beloved figure in the fan convention circuit, often appearing at Comic-Con and other events to meet with fans and sign autographs. He has also been involved in various charity initiatives, including the Star Wars: Force for Change campaign, which supports UNICEF and other organizations.

Throughout his career, Hamill has demonstrated his versatility and range as an actor, and has cemented his place as a beloved and iconic figure in popular culture.

Throughout his career, Mark Hamill has become synonymous with the character of Luke Skywalker, and his iconic portrayal of the character has cemented his place as a beloved figure in popular culture.
